**Beware of Maltitol Sweetener!**


This sweetener isn't for everyone. Maltitol, an alcohol sugar, can be difficult to digest for some people. If you consume it, you'll know quickly if you're one of the many who can't digest it. Symptoms include extreme intestinal bloating and cramping, along with excessive gas. Nausea, diarrhea, and headaches are also possible.

I learned this the hard way years ago when I fell in love with sugar-free chocolates by Suzanne Somers. They tasted like chocolate heaven, but the bliss was short-lived. The maltitol side effects hit me hard: intense bloating, excruciating abdominal cramping, and a wave of unpleasantness as the symptoms subsided. It was unlike anything I'd ever experienced, and I initially couldn't believe a low-calorie sweetener could be the culprit.  But the symptoms vanished when I stopped eating the chocolates.

A year later, I discovered the culprit again in delicious sugar-free popcorn. The taste was fantastic, but my heart sank when I saw "maltitol" listed as the sweetener. "This product might be called 'Molecular Gastronomy,' but don't let the scientific name intimidate you. I discovered it not for complex food science experiments, but for a much simpler, everyday use – making my own coffee creamer.

I love my coffee blonde and sweet, but store-bought flavored creamers are loaded with unhealthy fats. I prefer to avoid processed foods, believing they're not good for the body. On the other hand, I dislike the taste and texture of cold milk or cream in my hot coffee.

That's when I stumbled across this product on Amazon and had a brilliant idea: homemade creamer! I started experimenting with different combinations of low-fat (non-instant) milk powder, regular milk powder, and heavy cream.  

I found that using only heavy cream made the coffee too rich, and the powdered milk on its own was too expensive. My preferred ratio is a blend of one-third each. The non-instant low-fat milk powder offers a sweeter, fresher taste compared to regular instant low-fat milk, but it doesn't dissolve well in cold water – which isn't a problem for hot coffee.

For flavoring, I explored cocoa bean powder, vanilla bean powder, and caster (superfine) sugar. I mix up small batches, experimenting with spices like cinnamon and nutmeg to create my own unique flavored creamers. You could even use artificial sweeteners for a sugar-free option.

I store these small batches in jelly canning jars and use my food chopper/processor to blend everything thoroughly, ensuring the sugar doesn't settle at the bottom. However, remember to let it settle for a bit before opening the jar.

The homemade creamer tastes significantly better than store-bought alternatives, and the process is incredibly fun and rewarding, allowing you to unleash your creativity and invent your own flavor combinations. I'm eager to try incorporating essential oils, perhaps for a delightful chocolate/orange blend.

All the ingredients mentioned are readily available online. Don't hesitate to experiment and customize your creamer. You might choose to omit the low-fat milk or skip the flavorings altogether – the possibilities are endless! Homemade creamer also makes a thoughtful and unique housewarming or hostess gift.

While I primarily purchased this product for creamer, I'm confident that other enthusiasts of molecular gastronomy can explore its diverse applications in cooking. I'm excited to delve deeper into its culinary potential myself."





This product, marketed as "Molecular Gastronomy," might seem intimidating, but don't be fooled. I purchased it not for scientific culinary experiments, but for a more practical purpose: making my own coffee creamer.

Experimenting with ratios is key.  Using heavy cream alone resulted in a coffee that was excessively rich. Moreover, the powder's price makes it impractical to use solely.  I've found a 1/3:1/3:1/3 combination of all three milk powders to be ideal.

For flavoring, I've incorporated cocoa bean powder, vanilla bean powder, and caster (superfine) sugar. These ingredients, along with spices like cinnamon and nutmeg, allow me to create a diverse range of custom-flavored creamers.  Alternatively, you could substitute artificial sweetener powder.

I prepare small batches and store them in sterilized jelly canning jars.  I utilize a small food chopper/processor to blend everything thoroughly, ensuring the sugar disperses evenly and doesn't settle at the bottom.  Prior to opening, allow the mixture to settle for a short period.

The taste of these homemade creamers far surpasses that of store-bought varieties.  The process is enjoyable and allows for endless flavor experimentation.  I'm eager to explore the use of essential oils, potentially creating a delightful chocolate/orange blend.

The product name might sound intimidating ("Molecular Gastronomy"), but don't let that deter you. While it has applications in food science, I discovered a more down-to-earth use for it: making my own coffee creamer.

I prefer my coffee blonde and sweet, but store-bought flavored creamers are loaded with unhealthy fats.  I try to avoid processed food items as much as possible, believing they're not good for you. Using cold milk or cream isn't ideal either because I like my coffee hot.

Stumbling upon this product on Amazon sparked the idea for homemade creamer.  I purchased both low-fat (non-instant) and regular milk powder. The non-instant low-fat milk powder has a sweeter, fresher taste than the instant version, but it doesn't dissolve well in cold water. This isn't a problem for hot coffee, though.

Experimenting with the ratios is key. Using only heavy cream would make the coffee too rich. I found that mixing one-third each of the low-fat and regular milk powders works best. I also think the powder is too expensive to use alone.

For flavoring, I bought cocoa bean powder, vanilla bean powder, and caster (superfine) sugar.  I create small batches, adding spices like cinnamon and nutmeg to make my own unique creamers.  You could substitute artificial sweeteners if you prefer.

I store my creations in small jelly canning jars. I use a tiny food chopper/processor to blend everything, ensuring the sugar doesn't settle at the bottom. Give it a little time to settle before opening, though.

Homemade creamer tastes significantly better than store-bought options, and the experimentation is half the fun! I plan to try using essential oils next, aiming for a delicious chocolate/orange combination.

All the ingredients mentioned are readily available online.  Don't be afraid to experiment! You might not use any low-fat milk, or you might skip the flavorings entirely – it's entirely up to you. This homemade creamer also makes wonderful housewarming or hostess gifts.

I'm sure other "molecular gastronomy" enthusiasts can share more innovative uses for this product, and I'm eager to explore its culinary applications. However, the primary reason I purchased it was to make my own creamer, and it has exceeded my expectations.

I first learned about this cat food from my local pet store and decided to try a small bag for my two cats, a 3-year-old female and a 6-year-old male. My daughter cat loved it right away, while my older male cat, who had unfortunately been raised on low-quality cat food filled with cornmeal and other fillers, surprisingly enjoyed it too. He's usually resistant to dietary changes, but this one won him over.

My older cat is overweight, and our vet recommended switching him to soft food. However, he flatly refused. He's quite the picky eater! While he still consumes a bit too many calories, at least I know he's enjoying nutritious food.

I understand that this product is more expensive than most other cat foods on the market, but I refuse to feed my pets inferior alternatives marketed as healthy. I question why commercials often depict cats eating vegetarian diets primarily composed of cornmeal. Is that truly suitable for them?

I'm sticking with this brand for now, but I'll keep you updated.

**Update after 9 months:**

I'm happy to report that I've increased my rating from 4 to 5 stars. This cat food has been fantastic for my two cats. My older cat, Garfield, still eats a bit too much, but he's a large, inactive cat.  My female cat will be 4 soon, and she's incredibly healthy. She's small but full of energy. I tried the chicken version of Holistic Select, but Garfield seemed to prefer the sardine flavor, so we went back to this one. I've recently ordered the duck version and will update my review once they've tried it.

I first learned about Holistic Select cat food from my local pet store and decided to try a small bag for my two cats, a 3-year-old female and a 6-year-old male. My younger female cat loved it right away. My older male, who unfortunately had been raised on low-quality cat food loaded with corn and other fillers, usually resisted any dietary changes. For now, I'm sticking with Holistic Select, but I'll keep you updated on our experience.

It has truly been a great food for them. My older cat, Garfield, still eats a bit too much, but he's a large cat who isn't very active. Our female cat is now almost four years old and is in excellent health. She's small but incredibly happy and agile.

I briefly tried the chicken version of Holistic Select, but Garfield seemed to prefer this sardine flavor, so we switched back. I recently ordered the duck version and will provide an update once they've had a chance to try it.

Unlock the secret to creating stunning European-style fresh fruit tarts with this handy glaze packet! 

Inspired by a friend's request for a "strawberry" treat for a church pie auction, I'm about to bake one myself. This glaze is perfect for crafting delicious and relatively healthy fruit tarts. Simply bake a base (sponge cake, pate sucre, or even pre-baked pie crust in a muffin tin), layer with fresh, sliced fruit, and pour over the glaze. 

The magic happens as the glaze hardens at room temperature, holding the fruit together for easy slicing and allowing the beautiful arrangement to shine through.

This versatile glaze isn't just for tarts! I've also seen it beautifully adorn cheesecakes, securing a vibrant fruit topping. While I personally prefer to avoid rich cheesecakes, a fruit-glazed cheesecake is undeniably gorgeous.  Simply layer sliced fruit (cherries, strawberries, mangoes, or even poached lemon slices – my personal favorite!) on the cheesecake while it's still in the springform pan, pour on the glaze, let it set, and then carefully remove the springform. You'll be left with a captivating layer of fruit atop the cheesecake.

For those who enjoy a touch of indulgence, consider adding a layer of creme patisserie (a stabilized pastry cream) under the fruit in your tarts.

Whether you're a seasoned baker or just starting out, this glaze is a must-have in your pantry. It's vegan-friendly, made with tapioca starch, carrageenan, dextrose, cream of tartar, and locust bean gum, making it perfect for vegan desserts like tofu cheesecakes or fruit tarts with a nut crust base.

A beautifully glazed tart that's both delicious and surprisingly "healthier" than traditional options.

As the glaze sets at room temperature, it not only secures the fruit in place for easy slicing but also acts as a transparent showcase, letting the vibrant colors of the fruit shine through.  This versatile glaze isn't limited to tarts; it also elevates cheesecakes. While I'm personally not a cheesecake enthusiast, the addition of a fruit glaze transforms it into a work of art.  

Here's how to create a showstopping fruit-glazed cheesecake: adorn a cheesecake still in its springform pan with sliced fruit, then pour the glaze over it. Allow it to set before removing the pan, revealing a captivating layer of fruit nestled atop the creamy cheesecake. Cherries, strawberries, and mango slices all work beautifully, but my personal favorite is a delicate arrangement of sugar-poached lemon slices.

For a variation on the classic tart, try using a muffin pan to create mini tarts. Pre-bake each mold with a layer of pie crust or pate sucre for a perfectly shaped and textured mini tart. Fill them with fresh fruit, pour over the glaze, and for an extra touch of richness, add a layer of creme patisserie beneath the fruit. This creamy custard, stabilized with flour, adds a delightful extra dimension of flavor.

This glaze packet is a must-have for any baking enthusiast. Its vegan-friendly ingredients—tapioca starch, carrageenan, dextrose, cream of tartar, and locust bean gum—make it perfect for creating both vegan tofu cheesecakes and fruit tarts with a nut crust base, catering to a wide range of dietary needs and preferences.
